JProcessing

Class Processing.PImage

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.awt.Image
      • java.awt.image.BufferedImage
        • JProcessing.Processing.PImage
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.image.RenderedImage, java.awt.image.WritableRenderedImage, java.awt.Transparency
    Enclosing class:
    Processing

    public static class Processing.PImage
extends java.awt.image.BufferedImage
    PImage is the Image Class for JProcessing.

    PImage is A Subclass of BufferedImage. Besides the Ability to Store Image Files, PImage in JProcessing also offers Methods to Load and Save Images from Hard Drive as well as to Edit and Resize Images.

    The Dimension of a PImage can be Obtained by Variable width and height. However, their Value will be Updating through a Image TileObserver, thus not being Thread-safe. A short Delay is Expected from the Change of Size of a PImage to the change of width and height value of that same PImage.

    In Processing IDE, the pixels[] Array can be Accessed even before Calling loadPixels(), Although if done so pixels[] Array will not Hold any Data from the Original Image. But in JProcessing However, This will Not be Possible. Calling loadPixels() will be Mandatory before Accessing the pixels[] Array, otherwise Array pixels[] will Not be Initialized.
    This is a Known Issue of JProcessing. The Reason of Intentionally leaving it Unfixed is due to the fact that the Usage of pixels[] Array in Processing Code Programming is considerably Rare. Pre-allocating Space for pixels[] Array will effectively Double the Memory Usage of every PImage. It is quite Inefficient and Resource Consuming.

    Another Known Issue being the .resize() Method will Not change the actual Size of the PImage directly. Instead, the Resized Image will be Returned.

    Image Loading and Real-time Processing can be Slow especially when dealing with High-resolution Images. It is Advised that if Possible, all such Methods should be Done in Processing.setup() or Asynchronously. Avoid using them in Processing.draw() where the Method will be Invoked Repeatedly by every Frame.

    .requestImage(path) and .save(path) Methods will Utilize Multi-threading to Load and Save Image. Each time they are Invoked a new Thread will be started to Process their operations.

    Note that Although the Instructions on the Processing Website Forbids the Construction of PImage Class using Syntax new PImage(w,h), such Method is totally Allowed in JProcessing and will have the same result of Calling Method createImage(w,h).

    Todo: Improve Real-time Image Processing Performance (with Multi-threading) and Optimize current Multi-thread Efficiency Todo: Add additional Image Processing Functions such as filter() and blend()

    Since:
    1.0
    See Also:
    BufferedImage, PImage in Processing IDE

    • Field Detail

      • width

        public short width
        Width of the PImage (Read-Only)

      • height

        public short height
        Height of the PImage (Read-Only)

      • pixels

        public Processing.color[] pixels
        A color map of every pixel on the PImage, initialized and updated by calling loadPixels().

        Accessing the array before running loadPixels() will cause NullPointerException.

    • Constructor Detail

      • PImage

        public PImage(int w,
              int h)
        Create a new PImage with type ARGB and dimensions specified by w and h.

        This constructor works exactly the same as method createImage(w,h).

        Parameters:
        w - width of the image
        h - Height of the image

      • PImage

        public PImage(int w,
              int h,
              short type)
        Create a new PImage with type specified by type and dimensions specified by w and h.

        This constructor works exactly the same as method createImage(w,h,type).

        Parameters:
        w - width of the image
        h - Height of the image
        type - Format of the Image
        Should be one of the followings: Processing.RGB,
                 Processing.ARGB, Processing.ALPHA

        public Processing.PImage resize(int w,
                                int h)
        Resize the PImage.

        Different from Processing IDE, the dimension of the original PImage will be unaffected.

        Parameters:
        w - new width of the PImage
        h - new height of the PImage
        Returns:
        the resized instance of PImage
